ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a much greater understanding of Spanish and grew more confident and polished with writing and speaking.
I improved upon my Spanish vocabulary and became better at speaking with ease.
Developed grammar skills and worked towards proficiency in reading, writing, and speaking Spanish.

My Spanish speaking improved vastly after this course. Now that we're (mostly) back in person, language classes can really emphasize off-the-cuff speaking rather than the pauses and delays that often happen over Zoom which give you some time to prepare. I learned to express nuanced thoughts about literature, art, and politics in Spanish and reach for other words when I couldn't remember a particular word in Spanish. I also grew as a writer and reader as we read a novel called Las Batallas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength is the consistency of the class and the way exercised are geared towards practicing different skills; however, a weakness is that a lot of work was assigned, and because of that I didn't have the ability to take my time with the work sometimes it felt like there were a lot of things to tack off a list. But it was still manageable in the end.

This is a great course with not many weaknesses. The only one I can think of is the amount of projects we were asked to do outside of class time. They became tedious at times due to the frequency with which we completed them.

This class is interesting and we covered a lot of different grammar and vocabulary throughout the semester. The projects were interactive and engaging, but the course was very fast-paced and assignments were very long.

This course is generally strong. It is really difficult but you get as much out of it as you put in and if you do all those assignments you will get a lot better at Spanish. Its biggest weakness is what the projects/homework emphasizes. I appreciate that daily homework ensures we practice daily and it was instrumental to improving as much as I did in Spanish. But, on more than one occasion, I had to redo an assignment because I hadn't fully understood the assignment. This felt unnecessary because I had learned Spanish in the earlier version of the assignment; I had worked on a new concept and learned new vocabulary and practiced different tenses. So then I was just spending hours of time because I wrote about "xy" rather than "yx" (obviously not real content). I think homework could focus more on the Spanish learned rather than the content discussed

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend because it really helped me get back into the swing of learning Spanish at a higher level, and a lot of the class content was very interesting and went beyond surface level units.
I would recommend this course to a student who likes Spanish and is willing to work hard at it. If someone just wants to casually improve upon their language, this course is not for them.
Yes, if it is required. This class is a good way to develop your speaking skills.
